metadata.title: Trade Permits: Electrical, Plumbing, and Boiler/HVAC in San Francisco
notes: Trade permits are separate permit types from building permits — each trade has its own permit number
Trade permits can be pulled independently or bundled with a building permit
Electrical permits are governed by the SF Electrical Code (SFEC) — California Electrical Code + local amendments
Plumbing permits are governed by the SF Plumbing Code (SFPC) — California Plumbing Code + local amendments
Mechanical permits cover HVAC, ducting, exhaust, and fuel gas systems
All trade permit fees are separate from building permit fees — see fee-tables.json Table 1A-C and 1A-E

electrical_permits.description: Required for any new electrical work, panel upgrades, wiring changes, EV charger installation, or solar systems.
electrical_permits.governing_code: SF Electrical Code (SFEC) — California Electrical Code with local amendments

permit_types.name: Electrical Alteration Permit
permit_types.description: Standard permit for changes to existing electrical systems — adding circuits, outlets, panel work
permit_types.review_path: OTC or in-house depending on scope

permit_types.name: EV Charger Permit
permit_types.description: Permit for electric vehicle charging station installation — residential or commercial
triggers: Installing Level 2 or DC Fast Charger
New dedicated circuit for EV charging
Panel upgrade to support EV load
permit_types.review_path: OTC for residential single charger, in-house for multi-unit or commercial

permit_types.name: Solar PV Permit
permit_types.description: Photovoltaic system installation on residential or commercial buildings
permit_types.notes: Must coordinate with PG&E for interconnection; DBI permit covers structural and electrical

permit_types.name: New Construction Electrical
permit_types.description: Full electrical rough and finish for new buildings

permit_types.name: Fire Alarm System Permit
permit_types.description: Installation or modification of fire alarm/detection systems
triggers: Addition of smoke detectors beyond code minimum
Change of use requiring upgraded alarm

categories: Residential single-family: flat fee by scope
Solar: based on system kW capacity
fee_reference.notes: Small Business Month (May): pedestrian-level lighting electrical permits fee waived

inspection_requirements.description: Inspection of wiring before walls are closed — verifies conduit, wire gauge, junction boxes, grounding
Inspection of electrical service entrance and main panel before energizing
Final inspection after all devices, fixtures, and covers installed — before Certificate of Occupancy

commonly_bundled_with: Kitchen remodel building permit (panel upgrade, new circuits for appliances)
Bathroom remodel building permit (GFCI outlets, exhaust fan)
Commercial tenant improvement (complete new electrical layout)

plumbing_permits.description: Required for any work on water supply, drain/waste/vent (DWV), gas lines, or fixtures.
plumbing_permits.governing_code: SF Plumbing Code (SFPC) — California Plumbing Code with local amendments

permit_types.name: Plumbing Alteration Permit
permit_types.description: Standard permit for plumbing changes — moving fixtures, replacing water heater, adding hose bibs
permit_types.review_path: OTC for simple residential, in-house for complex or commercial

permit_types.name: Sewer Lateral Permit
permit_types.description: Permit for repair or replacement of the building sewer lateral from building to main
triggers: Pre-sale SSIP (Sewer System Improvement Program) compliance
permit_types.notes: Sidewalk and street restoration may require separate encroachment permit from DPW

permit_types.name: Backflow Prevention Permit
permit_types.description: Required for commercial properties with backflow prevention devices
triggers: Change of use to food service or medical

permit_types.name: Gas Piping Permit
permit_types.description: Permit for natural gas piping work — new lines, rerouting, appliance connections
triggers: Adding gas line for range, dryer, or fireplace
Converting from electric to gas appliances

permit_types.name: Grease Interceptor Permit
permit_types.description: Required for commercial kitchens — grease trap installation or replacement
triggers: New restaurant or food service establishment
Change of use to food service
Existing interceptor replacement or sizing upgrade

categories: Sewer lateral: fixed fee by pipe size

inspection_requirements.description: Inspection of drain, waste, vent (DWV) and supply lines before walls are closed
Pressure test of gas piping system before connecting appliances
Final inspection after all fixtures connected and operational

commonly_bundled_with: Restaurant tenant improvement (grease interceptor, commercial sink, hand-washing stations)

mechanical_permits.description: Required for HVAC systems, ventilation, exhaust fans (commercial-grade), boilers, and fuel gas systems.
mechanical_permits.governing_code: SF Mechanical Code (SFMC) — California Mechanical Code with local amendments

permit_types.name: HVAC Permit
permit_types.description: Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning system installation or replacement
triggers: New furnace or air handler installation
permit_types.review_path: OTC for replacement in-kind, in-house for new systems or complex commercial

permit_types.name: Boiler Permit
permit_types.description: Low-pressure and high-pressure boiler installation, replacement, or major repair
permit_types.notes: Operating engineers license required for high-pressure boilers; annual boiler inspection required

permit_types.name: Commercial Exhaust Permit
permit_types.description: Commercial kitchen exhaust systems, Type I/II hoods, makeup air
triggers: Type I or Type II hood installation

permit_types.name: Refrigeration Permit
permit_types.description: Commercial refrigeration systems — walk-in coolers, condensing units, ammonia systems
permit_types.review_path: OTC or in-house depending on scope

categories: Mechanical work: typically bundled with plumbing fees in 1A-C
Boiler: separate fee schedule by BTU rating

inspection_requirements.description: Inspection of ductwork, piping, and equipment before concealment
Final inspection after system is operational — includes test and balance for commercial systems

trade_permit_relationships.description: How trade permits relate to building permits and each other

key_rules.rule: Trade permits can be pulled independently of building permits
key_rules.explanation: A licensed electrician can pull an electrical permit directly without an accompanying building permit for simple work like adding an outlet or replacing a panel

key_rules.rule: Building permits often trigger trade permit requirements
key_rules.explanation: When a building permit involves plumbing or electrical work, separate trade permits are typically required in addition to the building permit

key_rules.rule: Trade permits have their own inspection sequence
key_rules.explanation: Each trade permit has rough-in and final inspections independent of building permit inspections, but final CO requires all trade permits to be finaled

key_rules.rule: Subcontractors must be licensed for their trade
key_rules.explanation: Only licensed electrical, plumbing, or mechanical contractors can pull trade permits; general contractors cannot pull trade permits
Trade permits have their own expiration dates — typically 180 days from issuance with extensions available

kitchen_remodel.building: Form 3 or 8 — layout changes or OTC no-plan for in-kind
kitchen_remodel.electrical: Panel circuit for new appliances, under-cabinet lighting
kitchen_remodel.plumbing: If moving sink or adding dishwasher

adu_addition.electrical: New subpanel or service upgrade, full residential wiring
adu_addition.plumbing: Full separate plumbing system — supply, DWV, gas

restaurant_ti.electrical: Commercial panels, 3-phase if needed, exhaust hood controls
restaurant_ti.plumbing: Grease interceptor, hand-washing stations, mop sink
restaurant_ti.mechanical: Type I exhaust hood, makeup air unit, refrigeration

bathroom_remodel.building: Form 3 or 8 — OTC if layout changes
bathroom_remodel.plumbing: If relocating toilet, tub, or shower

key_distinctions_from_building_permits.fee_structure: Trade permit fees are in Tables 1A-C (plumbing/mechanical) and 1A-E (electrical) — separate from building permit fees in 1A-A
key_distinctions_from_building_permits.licensing: Trade permits require licensed contractors; building permits may be owner-builder
key_distinctions_from_building_permits.review_stations: Trade permits route to ELEC, MECH-E, or PLMB stations in plan review — not to the main BLDG station
key_distinctions_from_building_permits.inspection_sequence: Trade inspections (rough-in, final) are scheduled separately from structural/building inspections
key_distinctions_from_building_permits.scope: Trade permits cover only the specific trade work; building permit covers structural, architectural, and life safety
